thread.title: ‘He’s more valuable as a forward than a defender’
thread.title_full: ‘He’s more valuable as a forward than a defender’

title: ‘He’s more valuable as a forward than a defender’
text:
Jason Dunstall, Matthew Pavlich and Cameron Mooney urge Carlton to play Jacob Weitering forward March 10, 2017 11:20pm Source: FOX SPORTS WE ALL know Jacob Weitering’s pedigree. 
The No. 1 draft pick is a bona fide star. As a junior he bullied forwards into submission with his intercept play, while his size and pace also combined to make him just as dangerous when he played forward. 
The question now for Carlton is: where should they play him? 
The Blues recruited Weitering to fill a hole in defence. And that’s where he stayed for almost all of his 20 matches in his debut season of 2016. 
But it has become apparent this preseason, if not beforehand, that Carlton is lacking fire power up forward. 
Matthew Wright was the club’s best goal kicker last year, with 22 majors. Bryce Gibbs was next best on 18. 
Weitering could provide the answer. 
At 195cm, he has the presence. Not to mention the hands. 
And on Friday night — despite Carlton’s loss to Fremantle — he looked every bit the part with 17 possessions, nine marks and a goal. 
Live stream EVERY game of the 2017 NAB AFL Women’s competition   > Jacob Weitering looked dangerous up forward for Carlton. Photo: Paul Kane/Getty Images Source: Getty Images 
Matthew Pavlich, a master of swing, suggested a move forward — even if not permanently — would be beneficial for the young gun and the Blues. 
“Sometimes for a player’s development it can be really worthwhile as well,” Pavlich told Fox Footy . 
“Regardless of where he plays the majority of his football, the development to play both forward and back — while some may see it as a distraction — it’s a great benefit for further down the track. 
“I had that experience in my career and found it invaluable.” 
Hawthorn champion Jason Dunstall agreed, saying Carlton should persist with their experiment of throwing Weitering forward. 
“I think you’re better to try and cover down back because of what he can give you up forward that no others can,” Dunstall said. 
“We know he can play back, but we’re starting to see he does have quality as a forward. 
“He’s a good size, he’s got good agility, pace, a good set of hands and if he’s a decent kick, gee I think he’s more valuable as a forward than as a defender.” 
Geelong premiership player Cameron Mooney suggested Weitering could not only impact in terms of goals, but as a link up forward who roams up the ground and connects chains of play. 
“We know he’s athletic, we know he can run and we know he can mark the ball,” Mooney told Fox Footy . 
“He’s a brilliant mark in the air. He judges the ball so well. We know he’s a great field kick and we know he’s a great field kick. He’s exactly what they need. 
“They need someone who can get them eight marks per game, around 15 possessions through that half forward line to be the link up player. Let’s hope Weitering’s the guy for Carlton.”
